We're seeing the first signs of AI engineering slop in our data (10,000 engineers across 500+ companies). To be clear, I think the data is still inconclusive but it's something we're going to stay very close to. The best measures of AI slop is AI code turnover: the % of AI code that is being re-written in the following three months and # of bugs created by AI written code. Both are lagging indicators. In 2025, code turnover stayed between 5.4% and 8.5% for most of the year. But then September and October spiked to 11.4% and 9.8%. This means code written in September-October has already been rewritten at a higher rate, despite being only 1-2 months old. 2025 proved teams are shipping faster with AI, but the long-term maintainability of that code is going to be the big question for 2026. â€¦more

I love pair programming, but most engineering teams have it backwards. They think it's too expensive and that AI can answer any question a peer could, so they avoid it. Here's why I prioritize it: 1. Speed on complex tasks If someone takes an approach that's way off base for a complex task, you review it, they fix it, and you review again. That cycle takes forever. You could have paired from the start and solved it in half the time. By the time you realize pair programming would have been faster, you've already sunk hours into the review cycle. 2. Team cohesion Pairing naturally brings people closer together. You develop a more cohesive understanding of the codebase. Every engineer has their own mental model of how the code works, like the classic story of blind men describing different parts of an elephant. Pair programming lets you fit those models together and figure out what's actually true. 3. Knowledge transfer Most of the clever keyboard shortcuts, debugging workarounds, and useful workflows I've learned came from watching someone else during pair programming! You can't get that from reading code or code reviews. ğ—›ğ—¼ğ˜„ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—±ğ—¼ ğ—¶ğ˜ ğ˜„ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¹? 1. Let the less experienced person drive This sounds backwards, but the driver sets the pace. If the more experienced person drives, they'll speed through, and the other person will keep saying, "wait, pause, go back" (or worse, check out entirely). If the less experienced person drives, the pace naturally matches their understanding level. 2. Both people need to be engaged It's like a pilot and copilot, not a driver and passenger. The person not driving should actively check assumptions and understand what's happening. If someone is just watching without understanding, you're doing it wrong. 3. Use it for the right tasks Pair programming works great for complex problems with no clear solution. It's perfect for onboarding when you want to download information quickly. But if you're moving buttons around or doing straightforward work you already know how to do, it's probably overkill. The barriers are real; both people need to be free at the same time. Someone has to initiate; you need a big block of time, and you can't focus on your own work. So teams default to solo work plus code review. But you miss out all the benefits which are harder to quantify. --- See the impact of pair programming: www.workweave.dev â€¦more

In the last 3 months I've interviewed 134 engineers, from students to CTOs (including Soham Parekh!). Here's why there's alpha in hiring junior engineers that the big companies aren't seeing. The current landscape: Teams have overcorrected away from junior talent. Engineering leaders got burned during COVID when remote mentoring failed spectacularly, and now they're gun-shy about investing in junior engineers. They can't see the long-term ROI, so it's easier to hire someone with 4+ years of experience even if their ceiling isn't as high. Meanwhile, CS programs keep churning out graduates who can't get their foot in the door anywhere, creating a massive pool of untapped talent. What big companies are missing: Junior engineers today are AI-native with no legacy patterns to unlearn, while senior engineers may be less quick to adopt. Companies are evaluating candidates with outdated criteria that don't account for AI proficiency, and using old assumptions about onboarding time when AI-savvy juniors can get up to speed much faster. The biggest blind spot is knowing where to find exceptional junior talent. A perfect example: engineers who applied to YC but didn't get in. These are often impressive people caught in what can be a coin flip selection process! How to find the right ones: Ask them about projects they've built, then drill deeper. Ask "Why did you build this?" and "How does that work?" Keep going until you hit the bottom of their knowledge. You're looking for the ones who light up talking about their projects and can explain their decisions. You'll enjoy talking to them and feel excited to have them. During her time as an EM in Google Compute Engine, Chaitali had to make a big headcount request for a new project: "We needed a new pre-prod environment that would allow us to test various complex scenarios for the product with efficiency and simplicity. Some also wanted to test specific applications, like SAP, that our customers often used on the VMs. My approach in such cases is to use the "Decoy Pricing Method". Decoy Pricing is a popular marketing strategy. It encourages customers to choose a specific product. Here is an example: Suppose you go to a cafe and see that a small cup costs $2.99 and a large cup is $7.99. The price difference seems large, so you are most likely to pick the small cup. If the cafe offers a medium cup for $6.99, you might choose the large cup instead. The difference is only a dollar, so it seems like a better deal. Here, the medium cup is the decoy. When requesting the headcount, I used the decoy pricing method to build the proposal: I provided three options for different headcount increases: Small, Medium, and Large. For each request, I outlined what we would create and how the system would work in terms of Speed, Ease, and Quality. One of the hardest parts about being a junior engineer is not knowing where you stand. Are you shipping enough? Are you working on the right things? How do you compare to more senior engineers? Having direct access to Weave 's data across 500 engineering teams, I figured I'd try to find some answers: The baseline: 3-5 PRs per week is a good target across all levels. Junior engineers average 3.4, intermediates 3.1, seniors 4.6, and staff 5.9. But the real difference between levels isn't the number of PRs. It's the complexity of what they're working on. If you only look at PR counts, you'd think staff engineers are doing 1.7x more work than juniors. But when you measure by code output and complexity, the multiplier is 3.8x. Junior engineers average 3.8 units of code output per week. Intermediate engineers are at 7.7. Seniors hit 6.9. Staff engineers reach 14.6. Staff engineers also conduct significantly more code reviews. They average 11.1 reviews per week compared to 5.1 for juniors and intermediates. And the quality of those reviews scales too, from 67 for juniors to 81 for staff. If you're a junior engineer wondering if you're on track, focus on three things: 1. Gradually increasing the complexity of problems you solve 2. Giving thoughtful code reviews 3. Writing durable code that doesn't need constant rewrites. The goal isn't shipping more PRs. It's becoming the engineer who can solve harder problems. â€¦more

This is a continuation from my last post. I've gotten more questions about my journey after the bootcamp and how I was able to get my first job. I spoke about how having a growth mindset gave me the confidence and the ability to learn difficult software engineering concepts. But getting my first software engineering job after a coding bootcamp was another journey. The bootcamp itself was great and I met a lot of great friends through it, but while it gave me a good foundation, it didn't prepare me for the job search. The job search, especially in software engineering, can be particularly excruciating. I learned that the hard way. To put things into perspectives, I did my applications through cold call job submissions because I was having no success in the other methods (references, connections, thoughtful messages). I decided it would be fun to track how many applications I put out there, so I can know how many I went through before I got my first job. I started applying and before I knew it I reached 100 applications. Then 200. Then 300. Then 400. Before I knew it, I ended up applying to 475 jobs before landing my first software job. From those 475 applications, only 3 responded. From those 3, I got rejected by 2 and only 1 offer. Which happened to be from Microsoft, this was one of my dream companies at the time. (Seattle native) I share all of this to say, to succeed, you need grit and perseverance. And for anyone struggling right now, just know, that for as many "no's" you may receive, you only need one "yes". I've received hundreds of no's before my big yes, and now, in hindsight, the rejections mean very little to me. So keep grinding and keep persevering and you will eventually make it! â€¦more
